newsitem.title: JAPAN: Little progress in KPC, ADNOC naphtha talks - traders.
newsitem.headline: Little progress in KPC, ADNOC naphtha talks - traders.

text.p: Little progress has been made in naphtha term contract talks between Asian customers and Middle Eastern suppliers, Kuwait and Abu Dhabi, oil product traders said on Friday.
Kuwait Petroleum Corp (KPC) is offering a $20 premium for one-year supply contracts starting in August.
"As long as KPC keeps its offer at $20, there will be little progress in the talks," one naphtha trader said.
"It is impossible for petrochemical end-users to pay such a high premium for full-range naphtha," one trader said.

Information on bidding levels for KPC material was scattered, but one South Korean buyer was said to have placed a bid at $13.50 per tonne over the mean of Middle Eastern quotes, and one Japanese firm at as low as around $8.00.
The premium for the current term year that started last August is $7.90, and the premium for holders of term contracts which began in March is $13.50.
In term talks with Abu Dhabi National Oil Co (ADNOC) for annual contracts starting in July, negotiations were deadlocked.
Clients' bids were at around $19 to $20 per tonne over the ADNOC formula for pentane-plus and "low-sulphur naphtha," while ADNOC's offer was $21.75, traders said.
"We are waiting for ADNOC's offer price to come down a little bit more," one trader said.
For the current term year, the ADNOC naphtha premium is $6.80.
Japan and South Korea are expected to import about two million tonnes of Kuwaiti naphtha, and 500,000 to 700,000 tonnes of ADNOC naphtha in the new term year, traders said.
